text: I'm Matt gross the frugal traveler for
the new york times over 12 weeks this
summer I drove across America in an old
Volvo eating cheaply sleeping cheaply
and hopefully doing it with a bit of
style when I started the trip I wanted
to remain anonymous you wouldn't see my
face on any of the videos in the end no
one recognized me no one recognized the
car no reason to hide any longer I york
times three when I set out on this road
trip I was as ambitious as I was naive I
really thought I would be able to see
almost all of the four lower 48 states
in one go this is my summer from New
York I'm driving south through Baltimore
and down the eastern shore of maryland
and virginia into the Carolinas and
through the deep south been back north
up through Tennyson Kentucky to the
Midwest and the Great Lakes and had to
skip Minnesota which angered my mother
Arizona went out Utah went out Nevada
went out plans change but that's part of
a road trip what weeks sounds like a lot
of time so do a cross-country road trip
but we're talking about visiting every
place in America that's no time at all
you need years
so in 12,000 miles of driving I saw a
lot of a lot of different parts of
America but what was always much more
important to me was the people I met
along the way yes I'm writing a piece
right now in the pictographic language
of the Big Mac my fingers aren't really
doing anything it's all in my mouth it's
MacGyver did I like to say America is a
country of you know vast gee you know
Geographic differences cultural
differences but it's the people that
meant the most to me Columbus Indiana
for example it's a really amazing little
small town with fantastic modernist
architecture but what I really
appreciated more was the couchsurfing
family that I wound up staying with
perfect strangers you know being up
their house to you bringing your bed za
really she's a doctor he's a artist and
stay-at-home dad they have three kids
three six and nine years old and what
was really interesting is they
absolutely made me feel like part of
their family it was just so homey and
that's not it's not the sort of thing
you expect to find on a road trip but
it's absolutely the most wonderful I do
a lot of carving all my sculptures kind
of end up now looking like old toys just
like the Sailor like the creepy clown I
met a lot of people completely randomly
on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in
South Dakota I just parked to look
around wounded knee and was approached
by this Native American guide he showed
me around we talked about the history of
Wounded Knee and they wound up just
inviting me to stay at his house with
his family yeah when I would dance
had a similar to the ghost nest i was
given 1890 just come camp pop and just
pay respects my experience with JT and
my experience with the scenery nose in
indiana really sort of brought home to
me two things i noticed throughout the
summer everywhere in America one is that
this is still very segregated country
but on the other hand just as ubiquitous
is American hospitality the most amazing
moment to me was in decorah in
northeastern Iowa got there late at
night checked into an affordable bed and
breakfast and walked down the street to
the local bistro actually the only
bistro in town called la rana by the end
of the night the owners Joni and Mark
said hey why don't you come and stay
with us for a few days you got a spare
bedroom it's yours what's just an
impulsive notion like oh oh I just stay
here it's really cool place we could get
around Sundays and we just felt you know
your pen good energy so okay cool yeah
um yes five minutes after you were there
hey want you to stay with us joni and
marks generosity really showed me that
the right way to approach this American
road trip or really any trip anywhere is
to be open to be nice to be polite and
to say yes to everything that anyone
ever offers you
Oh
